newsitem.title: USA: Dog gets his own Web page in U.S. Senate.
newsitem.headline: Dog gets his own Web page in U.S. Senate.

text.p: The first guide dog to set paw on the Senate floor now has his own Internet site, Senate e-mail address and on-line photo gallery.

Beau, a guide dog for a visually impaired aide to Oregon Sen. Ron Wyden, became the centre of dispute when a senator objected to the yellow labrador entering the Senate chamber. The matter went to a vote on Tuesday and Beau won as the body voted to allow guide dogs on the floor.
Beau now has a Web page. Wyden's office decided to set up the site and e-mail address after receiving many e-mail letters from children who wanted to know more about the dog.
The home page features information about the controversy, a photo gallery of Beau and her owner, Moira Shea, and links to related home pages, including Leader Dogs for the Blind.
The site is http://www.senate.gov/wyden/beau/beau.htm. Beau can be reached by e-mail at beau@wyden.senate.gov.
